awd_titl_txt: Investigating Sources of Excess Carbon and DELTA14C Anomalies During the Last Glacial Termination
awd_abstract_narration:
Recognizing that greenhouse gas variability played a primary role in Earth's largest climate changes, the challenge now is to discover what processes are responsible for variations in atmospheric greenhouse gases that accompany large climate changes.  The Pleistocene glacial/interglacial cycles are arguably some Earth's largest and most dramatic climatic changes associated with variations in atmospheric pCO2 and methane. But after three decades of research there is no scientific consensus on the mechanisms responsible for the variations in greenhouse gas concentrations. Recent discoveries have revealed secretes about the Earth's carbon system that prompted the hypothesis being investigated with this award. The hypothesis argues that the flux of CO2 into and out of rocks and sediments that blanket marine hydrothermal systems varied with temperature during glacial-interglacial cycles. This is because CO2 and CO2-rich fluids from hydrothermal vents become denser than seawater as temperatures cool during glaciations.  The denser CO2 accumulates in rocks and sediments until the oceans warm at the glacial terminations. When temperatures rise during a glacial termination, CO2 becomes buoyant and is released into the Ocean.  Carbon released from hydrothermal systems carries distinct geochemical fingerprints that are imprinted on marine sediments. This project will use geochemical measurements to investigate whether these geochemical signals were imprinted on sediments at the last glacial-to-interglacial transition. Preliminary evidence supports this hypothesis. The results of this investigation could inform not only our understanding of how geologic processes influenced the Earth's past climate, it could also inform our understanding of how sensitive geologic reservoirs of carbon are to rising ocean temperature in the future. This award will also support  ongoing participation in STEM training at the University of Southern California through research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and high school seniors.

New Boron isotope and 14C records from marine sediments indicate there was a significant increase in the flux of 14C-depleted CO2 from the eastern equatorial Pacific to the atmosphere during the last glacial termination as atmospheric pCO2 was rising. The source of excess carbon and the reason for the increased flux of 14C-depleted CO2 is not currently known. However, two different hypotheses have been put forth to explain the deglacial history. One hypotheses calls upon ventilation of a formally isolated abyssal water mass through the Southern Ocean and transport of the ventilated carbon to the tropics via intermediate waters. An alternative hypothesis calls upon release of geologic carbon into the tropical Ocean from hydrothermal reservoirs in response to ocean warming during the deglaciation. This research seeks to determine which of these two hypotheses is correct. Each of the hypothesized mechanisms would have left a different geochemical fingerprint on the intermediate waters that fed the equatorial Pacific upwelling system. The so-called "abyssal ventilation hypothesis" predicts that the source waters that contributed carbon to the equatorial undercurrent would have had the lowest Delta14C signature and the lowest [CO3=]. Alternatively, if the increased carbon flux in the equatorial Pacific resulted from release of carbon from localized geologic sources, the most depleted Delta14C values and the lowest [CO3=] would have occurred near the sites of carbon release. These two mechanisms will be distinguishable with measurements of 14C ages of benthic foraminifera, a proxy for changes in Delta14C and in B/Ca, a proxy for changes in [CO3=]. Stable isotope data (benthic foraminiferal delta13C and delta18O) will augment the 14C and B/Ca results for characterizing intermediate water properties and mixing of source water signals in the equatorial undercurrent system. Researchers at USC will make these proxy measurements and evaluate the results using an Earth System model of intermediate complexity (cGENIE) that is able to simulate how the isotope and [CO3=] gradients would change at intermediate depths in the Pacific if carbon was released from the Southern Ocean and/or from localized sources near hydrothermal vents.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to test a provocative new hypothesis put forth by the PI (Stott) that calls upon geologic processes to affect the storage and release of geologic carbon to/from the oceans during glacial cycles. In 2009 the PI (Stott) discovered and published what was at that time the largest radiocarbon anomaly ever observed in marine records from the past 30ky. That discovery prompted further research into the origins of that anomaly, and this led to a publication of what has been a highly provocative new hypothesis to explain some portion of the systematic variations in atmospheric pCO2 that accompanied each glacial/interglacial cycle of the past million years. That provocative hypothesis argues that the flux of carbon from geologic sources to the ocean/atmosphere system is not a constant as has been the long-held view about the carbon cycle on glacial time scales. The hypothesis put forth by the PI argues that the flux of carbon from geologic sources is reduced during glaciations and is increased during deglaciations such that the climate system is responding to geologic processes as well as to ocean and biological influences. This hypothesis met with considerable resistance from the Paleoceanography community that has sought to explain the variations in atmospheric pCO2 by ocean and biological processes alone. However, the large radiocarbon anomaly discovered by the PI is far too large to be explained by ocean processes alone.

                Since the original discovery and publication of the hypothesis the PI has received funding from the NSF to further investigate the provocative hypothesis. The results of this NSF-funded research have led to new findings that further support the hypothesis. These results have been published and new findings are currently in papers under review. Among our more recent findings is evidence that CO2 was released from sea floor pockmarks that cover a vast region of the Chatham Rise in the southwestern Pacific. The pockmarks (depressions) have puzzled scientists for years. They were initially thought to have formed when subsurface CH4 escaped and caused the sediments to be displaced. However, research conducted by the PI and colleagues have shown that CO2, not CH4 was released from the Chatham Rise during the last glacial termination, the time when the pockmarks last formed.  This discovery has important implications for past changes in pCO2 because seismic data collected by our team has demonstrated that large numbers of pockmarks have formed repeatedly at each of the previous glacial terminations, making the Chatham Rise a potentially significant source of carbon to the oceans. These findings have prompted the PI to lead an initiative to bring the International Ocean Drilling Program to the Chatham Rise to core into earlier glacial cycles and document the releases of carbon that accompanied earlier pockmark phases.  Importantly, other researchers have begun to find evidence that further supports this hypothesis. And while there remains considerable resistance to this hypothesis within the Paleoceanography community, this is slowly changing.

                The findings published by PI and his colleagues have potentially important broader impacts that go beyond explaining the natural variations in the concentration of atmospheric pCO2 during glacial cycles. This is because the geologic processes that have regulated the flux of geologic carbon to the ocean and atmosphere in the past may be sensitive to changing ocean temperatures occurring today. For example, a large lake of liquid CO2 was discovered in the back-arc basin of the Okinawa trough. This lake of CO2 occurs at ~1000m water depth and is held in place by a thin layer of solid (hydrate) CO2 at the sediment/water interface. Currently the temperatures in the northwest Pacific at ~1000m water depth are with just a few degrees of the destabilization point of hydrate. Consequently, a warming of ocean temperatures over the coming century could potentially destabilize this large reservoir of carbon and release it to the ocean. This is but one example of what may be many such reservoirs located throughout the oceans where CO2 could be released in the future. So, with the support of the National Science Foundation our ongoing research seeks to locate and study geologic sources of carbon within the ocean that could lead to a fundamental new understanding of the Earth natural carbon cycle.
